question.body: Suppose that based on a random sample, a 95% confidence interval for the mean hours slept (per day) among graduate students was found to be (6.5, 6.9). What is the margin of error of this confidence interval?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Because 6.7 is the center of the confidence interval, it must be the sample mean. Recall that the width of the confidence interval is twice the margin of error.
Incorrect. 0.4 is the width of the confidence interval. Recall that the width is twice the margin of error.
Correct. Because the width of the confidence interval is 0.4 (6.9 - 6.5), the margin of error must be 0.4 / 2 = 0.2.

question.body: Suppose that based on a random sample, a 99% confidence interval for the mean hours slept (per day) among college freshmen was found to be (6.5, 7.3). What is the sample mean x̄?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The width of the confidence interval is 0.8. Recall that the confidence interval for the population mean µ is centered at the sample mean.
Incorrect. 0.4 is half the width of the confidence interval and is therefore the margin of error. Recall that the confidence interval for the population mean µ is centered at the sample mean.
Correct. 6.9 is the center of the confidence interval [(6.5 + 7.3)/2] and is therefore the sample mean.

body.p: In a recent study, a random sample of “Intro Stats” students taking an introductory statistics course were asked about the number of hours they spend each week studying for their statistics class. Using the collected data, a 95% confidence interval and a 99% confidence interval for the population mean were constructed.
Which of the following could represent the 95% and 99% confidence intervals?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that the 99% confidence interval is wider than the 95% confidence interval

Incorrect: It is true that the 99% confidence interval must be wider than the 95% confidence interval, however since both confidence intervals were constructed using the same data, they must both be centered at the same sample mean. In this case, the 95% confidence interval is centered at 6.1 ((6.8 + 5.4) / 2) and the 99% confidence interval is centered at 6.15 ((7.0 + 5.3) / 2).

Correct. The 99% confidence interval is wider than the 95% confidence interval, and since both confidence intervals were constructed using the same data, they are both centered at the same sample mean (6.1 in this case).

Incorrect. Recall that the 99% confidence interval must be wider than the 95% confidence interval. Also, since both confidence intervals were constructed using the same data, they should both be centered at the same sample mean. In this case, the 95% confidence interval is centered at 6.1 ((6.8 + 5.4) / 2) and the 99% confidence interval is centered at 6.05 ((6.6 + 5.5) / 2).
